user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime:
```c
void OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(uint32 msecs, struct timespec *tm)
{
    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);

    /* add the delay to the current time */
    tm->tv_sec += (time_t)(msecs / 1000);
    /* convert residue ( msecs )  to nanoseconds */
    tm->tv_nsec += (msecs % 1000) * 1000000L;

    if (tm->tv_nsec >= 1000000000L)
    {
        tm->tv_nsec -= 1000000000L;
        tm->tv_sec++;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The pointer tm is used as an output parameter and is written to by clock_gettime and by subsequent assignments (tm->tv_sec, tm->tv_nsec). Making it a pointer to const would prevent these valid modifications and would conflict with the clock_gettime prototype, so Rule 8.13 is not violated here. (A violation would occur if tm were only read and never modified yet declared as a non-const pointer.)
